Rodger N. Baldwin, Director of the American Civil Liberties Union, will address a
special meeting of the Johns
Hopkins University Liberal
Club to be held at 6.45 P. M.
this evening on the second
floor of Levering Hall.
All members of the university
who are interested in the interesting speeches and discussions attendant upon affairs
of the Liberal Club are cordially invited to attend and are
kindly requested to make reservation with L. Teper, Box
990, University Post Office.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 16, 1930

June Week
* * *

THESENIOR BALL AND
OTHER AFFAIRS
In the past few weeks we have
sketched in this column some of the
high spots of the 1930 June Week.
But there will be many other affairs
which we have not yet described.
The Senior Banquet for instance
on Thursday, June 5, at the Southern Hotel. This will be a formal affair with several short talks delivered by the prominent officials of
the University.
Then on Saturday afternoon the
Committee has succeeded in arranging a lacrosse game that is expected
to prove one of the best of the season. The Olympics will play a team
never before seen in Baltimore, the
Penn Athletic Club of Philadelphia.
The ability of the Olympics is beyond doubt and their opponents will
give them plenty to worry about.
The Penn A. C. is known as one of
the foremost athletic clubs in this
country and everyone that carries
their colors is a true athlete.
Saturday evening Bill Banks of
the Class of '29, "Pep" Legum and
Roberta Malambre, two former
Hopkins co-eds will produce a play
either in the Homewood Playshop
or the C. E. Hall. The play given by
these three last June Week proved
one of the features of the festivinevys-letter—Villeponteaux X
ties and we are very fortunate in
baying them produce another play
for us,. Following the play there
will be a dance in Alumni Memorial
Hall. In addition to these affairs,
June Week will also have a tea
dance, several teas, and Senior StepSinging.
The big day for all will be Tuesday, June 10. No need to remind
the Seniors that they receive their
degrees at the Lyric at 4 p. m.
Tuesday night is the Senior Ball.
The ball will be held in the main
'ballroom of the Alcazar and will
begin at 11 p. m. The affair will be
formal as is customary. Not only
-will the main ball room of the Alcazar be available, but also the large
gymnasium and quite probably the
smaller ball room as well.

1

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
Indian students at the University
of Michigan met recently and drew
up a resolution protesting against
the arrest of Mahatmi Ghandi, leading figure in the agitation for home
rule in India. The 'resolution reads
as follows: "Indian students at the
University of Michigan assert their
rights as citizens of India and
strongly condemn the action of the
British Government in India in arresting Mahatmi Ghandi, who is the
symbol of peace and love. If the people of India resort to violence, the
full responsibility will rest upon the
government that has been unable to
understand the peaceful methods of
the National Congress of India."
Copies of the resolution were forwarded to a London Indian magazine, the National Congress of India, the Pan-Asiatic Conference
and the League of Nations.

Juniors at the University of Idaho
awarded a prize to the man wearing
the dirtiest pair of corduroy trousers to a recent dance. The motive
behind the action was an attempt
to stimulate informality at the affair.

Every student at Tufts who fails
to report to the office after his last
class preceding a vacation and before his'first class following a vacation is subject to a fine of two dollars.

A corner o.f a Princeton barber
shop is made dear to the hearts of
all Tiger men by containing the goal
posts from the Yale-Princeton football game of 1925. The posts now
-serve as a hatrack for students
while undergoing tonsorial alterations.

their Junior Prom was a big success except for the overcrowding

down next year's crowd was that
tickets be sold at the price of $7.50.
This is a fine suggestion if they
want to get rid of the Prom.

team will look impressive. Let's kill

DEAN BERRY PRESIDES
Matter Brought Up By President Ames
A meeting of the Interfraternity
Board was held last Monday afternoon, May 12th, in order to discuss plans for the adoption of a midyear rushing agreement. Dean Berry
presided over the meeting which was
instigated by a letter from the President. Several reasons for the proposed change were given. The main
argument presented were: firstly,
that the rusher-s and rushees are
not given time enough to get wellacquainted with one another, thus
necessitating too many mistakes;
secondly, that the rushing period of
about six weeks is a time when practically no work is accomplished, and
lastly, that the first year men are inclined to put on airs alter an early
pledging, which will have a serious
effect on their college carer.

A milestone of Telephone progress
This marker is used to show the position of
a new type of underground cable line. It is
also a monument to the Bell System policy
of constantly improving established methods
and developing new ones.
For years underground telephone cables
have been laid in hollow duct lines especially
constructed for the purpose. By this newly
developed supplementary method they can
be buried directly in the ground without con-

duit—and, under many conditions, at a saving of time and money.
To do this it was necessary to develop
a new type of cable, many kinds of special
equipment including labor-saving installation
machinery, and to work out an entirely new
installation procedure.
Progress means change. The Bell System
holds no procedure so sacred that it is not
open to improvement.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 16, 1930

June Week
* * *

THESENIOR BALL AND
OTHER AFFAIRS
In the past few weeks we have
sketched in this column some of the
high spots of the 1930 June Week.
But there will be many other affairs
which we have not yet described.
The Senior Banquet for instance
on Thursday, June 5, at the Southern Hotel. This will be a formal affair with several short talks delivered by the prominent officials of
the University.
Then on Saturday afternoon the
Committee has succeeded in arranging a lacrosse game that is expected
to prove one of the best of the season. The Olympics will play a team
never before seen in Baltimore, the
Penn Athletic Club of Philadelphia.
The ability of the Olympics is beyond doubt and their opponents will
give them plenty to worry about.
The Penn A. C. is known as one of
the foremost athletic clubs in this
country and everyone that carries
their colors is a true athlete.
Saturday evening Bill Banks of
the Class of '29, "Pep" Legum and
Roberta Malambre, two former
Hopkins co-eds will produce a play
either in the Homewood Playshop
or the C. E. Hall. The play given by
these three last June Week proved
one of the features of the festivinevys-letter—Villeponteaux X
ties and we are very fortunate in
baying them produce another play
for us,. Following the play there
will be a dance in Alumni Memorial
Hall. In addition to these affairs,
June Week will also have a tea
dance, several teas, and Senior StepSinging.
The big day for all will be Tuesday, June 10. No need to remind
the Seniors that they receive their
degrees at the Lyric at 4 p. m.
Tuesday night is the Senior Ball.
The ball will be held in the main
'ballroom of the Alcazar and will
begin at 11 p. m. The affair will be
formal as is customary. Not only
-will the main ball room of the Alcazar be available, but also the large
gymnasium and quite probably the
smaller ball room as well.

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
Indian students at the University
of Michigan met recently and drew
up a resolution protesting against
the arrest of Mahatmi Ghandi, leading figure in the agitation for home
rule in India. The 'resolution reads
as follows: "Indian students at the
University of Michigan assert their
rights as citizens of India and
strongly condemn the action of the
British Government in India in arresting Mahatmi Ghandi, who is the
symbol of peace and love. If the people of India resort to violence, the
full responsibility will rest upon the
government that has been unable to
understand the peaceful methods of
the National Congress of India."
Copies of the resolution were forwarded to a London Indian magazine, the National Congress of India, the Pan-Asiatic Conference
and the League of Nations.

their Junior Prom was a big success except for the overcrowding

down next year's crowd was that

want to get rid of the Prom.

To Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Sure, we'll beat St. Johns. Did
you ever hear of a great big Blue
gleam that >couldn't beat the
Johnnies ? Last year, we had some
tough breaks, but this year it's the
Black and Blue for another championship. So let's all get together
and get out to Homewood Field for
the game, and unless you're lucky
enough to be an escort, sit in the
cheering section, and give the boys
a hand when they need it. And by
the way, wear a hat, so that the old
funeral song for the dead St. Johns'
team will look impressive. Let's kill
the Johnnies with a bang.
Loyal One.

DEAN BERRY PRESIDES
Matter Brought Up By President Ames
A meeting of the Interfraternity
Board was held last Monday afternoon, May 12th, in order to discuss plans for the adoption of a midyear rushing agreement. Dean Berry
presided over the meeting which was
instigated by a letter from the President. Several reasons for the proposed change were given. The main
argument presented were: firstly,
that the rusher-s and rushees are
not given time enough to get wellacquainted with one another, thus
necessitating too many mistakes;
secondly, that the rushing period of
about six weeks is a time when practically no work is accomplished, and
lastly, that the first year men are inclined to put on airs alter an early
pledging, which will have a serious
effect on their college carer.

A milestone of Telephone progress
This marker is used to show the position of
a new type of underground cable line. It is
also a monument to the Bell System policy
of constantly improving established methods
and developing new ones.
For years underground telephone cables
have been laid in hollow duct lines especially
constructed for the purpose. By this newly
developed supplementary method they can
be buried directly in the ground without con-

duit—and, under many conditions, at a saving of time and money.
To do this it was necessary to develop
a new type of cable, many kinds of special
equipment including labor-saving installation
machinery, and to work out an entirely new
installation procedure.
Progress means change. The Bell System
holds no procedure so sacred that it is not
open to improvement.
